thread.title: Sneak peek: A glimpse into 'National Parks'
thread.title_full: Sneak peek: A glimpse into 'National Parks'

title: Sneak peek: A glimpse into 'National Parks'
text:
USA TODAY gets a preview of 'National Parks Adventure,' arriving Feb. 12, 2016, in IMAX theaters. The project celebrates 100 years of the National Park Service with a stunning look at the nation's shared parks. Here, Rachel Pohl paints the landscapes of Bryce Canyon in Utah. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen The film will feature images from more than 30 National Parks, with stunning views such as this sunrise over Crater Lake National Park in southern Oregon. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Sunrise reflection on Jackson Lake, part of Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen The film follows mountaineer Conrad Anker, here climbing the frozen waterfalls in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore in Michigan. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Half Dome rises 4,737 feet above the Merced River on the floor of Yosemite Valley in California. Dmitri Fomin Fullscreen The Great Fountain Geyser erupts in Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Sunrise over the hoodoo rock formations of Bryce Canyon in Utah. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen The team cross-country skis through an ice cave in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore in Michigan. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Mesa Arch overlooks Canyonlands National Park in Utah. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Giant sequoia trees grow in Mariposa Grove in California's Yosemite National Park. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Arches National Park in Utah is home to more than 2,000 known arches. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen The film features a re-enactment of John Muir and President Teddy Roosevelt’s famous camping trip in Yosemite Valley to discuss the future of a National Parks system. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Environmentalist and actor Robert Redford narrates the film. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Director Greg MacGillivray and stereographer Doug Lavender position the 3-D IMAX camera to film Devils Tower in Wyoming. MacGillivray Freeman Films Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Half Dome rises 4,737 feet above the Merced River on the floor of Yosemite Valley in California. (Photo: Dmitri Fomin)
27 CONNECT 30 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE The National Park Service is getting the perfect present for its 100th anniversary in 2016 — its very own stunning 3-D IMAX film highlighting national treasures.
National Parks Adventure (in theaters Feb. 12, 2016) will take viewers on what director Greg MacGillivray calls the ultimate off-trail adventure through many of the nation's most beautiful wild parks, narrated by environmentalist filmmaker Robert Redford.
"There have been films about the Grand Canyon, Niagara Falls and Yellowstone National Park," says MacGillivray. "But an overall film about the national parks waited until this 100th anniversary. It's now so much more poignant and meaningful, and celebrating 100 years is a wonderful thing."
USA TODAY
'Everest' hit with cold, hard challenges
The film follows world-class mountaineer Conrad Anker, his adventure photographer stepson Max Lowe and artist Rachel Pohl as they rock climb, mountain climb and hike through Utah's Arches, Canyonlands and Zion national parks.
MacGillivray also utilized time-lapse camera crews, a helicopter camera and a 3-D IMAX camera to gloriously depict more than 30 national parks over 400 shooting days on rich IMAX 15/70 film.
USA TODAY
Joseph Gordon-Levitt takes 'The Walk' on wire
Even with the film essentially complete, the team is still capturing more striking images from the parks. "We have time to perfect everything," says MacGillivray, speaking by phone after filming another sunset at Nevada's Great Basin National Park.
"The big thing about this kind of photography, as Ansel Adams would tell you, is patience," says MacGillivray. "You have to get to the place and figure out what kind of shot you want. And then you wait for the lighting, the clouds and all the conditions to be right. Sometimes it comes and sometimes it doesn't."
The IMAX film will feature images from over 30 National Parks, with stunning views such as this sunrise over Crater Lake National Park in southern Oregon. (Photo: MacGillivray Freeman Films)
Featured parks include some of the most famous locations in the world: Yellowstone, the Everglades, the Redwoods, the Grand Canyon. But National Parks Adventure also showcases relatively undiscovered gems such as the Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore in upper Michigan.
Shooting this winter landscape required snowmobile trekking and two weeks of frigid work. But the ice-filled scenes were so spectacular that they became the film's end sequence.
"It was completely unexpected and incredibly beautiful. The lake is frozen, so it had this stark and arctic feeling," says Anker, who ice climbed the area. "Normally, you're either thinking Yellowstone or Glacier National Park, but to see this kind of ice beauty in the Midwest is truly a treat. It's wonderful to bring it into the national park conversation."
The film follows mountaineer Conrad Anker, here climbing the frozen waterfalls in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore in Michigan. (Photo: MacGillivray Freeman Films)
